number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												Even on sale it was a complete waste of money. Like other reveiwers have said, it's basically a simple flashcard game by clicking on objects. No really difficult or obscure words, either-- not in the languages I already have some knowledge of, anyway.I got this despite the bad reviews because I saw a discussion on the forums about what they were going to add next-- because the tiny apartment is VERY limiting. If I was able to explore a bigger and more diverse world, I would actually probably give this game a solid rating and wouldn't have asked for a refund. -- Anyway, when I was really underwhelmed by the content currently available, I went back to that forum post to see if they were going to add anything new any time soon --- and realised the discussion had happened several years ago. They probably aren't going to add anything else. If you want to practice a language (after getting basic skills from pretty much ANYTHING ELSE), a good way to practice languages is use those language options in your game. A lot of games on Steam have quite a few language compatabilities-- will full audio and subtitles oftentimes. It'll tell you generally what it supports on a game's store page.But no, for real, to keep up with my Italian, I just play games in Italian. All the Bioshock games have a REALLY solid Italian language version-- with proper colloquialisms and everything! The Metro games have a really solid Russian language option. Anyway, just keep an eye out. Most BIG titles will have some language options-- and ones developed not in a primarily English speaking place usually have the options of those areas. The Talos Principle for example has a LOT of slavic language options, most notably to me, Croatian. <3 But yeah, basic knowledge (be at least conversational, I guess?) is required to be able to practice well with it. But there are a lot of ways to do that. -- And those ways would NOT be by playing this game. It does not prepare you for anything except knowing what a few houshold objects are called. I would recommend podcasts, youtube, finding friends who want to learn english and you want to learn their language and just talking back and forth, etc.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												You take the role of an unfortunate young man unable to leave his apartment, seemingly stuck in time. The only other living things with him being his cat who never wakes from her slumber, and a few plants, one of which is neglected through lack of watering. A quick look at the clock in the kitchen reveals that time stands still. It becomes apparent that you're stuck in some sort of time loop, or that time has somehow frozen. The outside tempts you through pictures of the protagonist and a young woman whom I assume is his girlfriend. Various posters and books strewn around tease the existence of a world outside. Forms of communication like your computer and television do nothing. The television looping the same video over and over, the "portatil" and "ordenador" stuck on the same webpage, a phamplet pushed through a mail slot...it's all a reminder to his predicament.    Stuck, the young man does what any sane person would do. Learn a new language. There are 420 words to be learned, and you must help him learn them. Lindo, Techo, Muro, he learns these new words. Portatil, pelota; the man keeps going. You know its all futile in the end, but you must keep going. I'm about 100 words away from 420 (great reference there BTW), but I fear I might think "now what..." when I get there.     There's a silver lining to all this for you the player. In alternate versions, you learn new words like: "cama", "寝床", and "lit." Words you can use with the beautiful women of this world (warning: you might get slapped). That said, this is a WONDERFUL language reference in my opinion. Team it up with a good education, the "Duolingo" app, or a nice girlfriend (or bf, or both) if you're into multicultrual dating. It's a great supplement to your language learning arsenal. I try to keep my PC library efficent by getting rid of games I've finished, and files I don't need any longer. But this "game" Influent...It's going to stay on my hardrive for a loong time.      My version is Spanish, and any additional version is USD 4,99. Unless you're Jason Bourne, a linguistic professor, or a robot, I would not recommend buying more than a few in a short time span. The price tag of USD 9.99 is very well worth it IMHO. A good tip to help out: change UI language settings to whichever one you're trying to learn.

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												The first few words of the product description are "Influent is a Language Learning Game.." which apparently, it is not.Case in point: I wanted to try learn Japanese, and there was a special offer a long time ago so I didn't have to pay much to get the game, so I figured I would give it a shot and try learn some Japanese.  You are placed into a room, walking around and clicking on things, 'collecting words'.  Apparently at some point they test you on these words, but they don't show you HOW to learn a word!  This game is basically a test to see if you are good enough to continue learning new words, but if you don't know how to speak the language at all, this is useless.If I got the German or French version I would probably have a different opinion (and I might get those versions at some point because they seem more useful to me) since they use 'english/latin' characters I am familiar with.  I can see the text "der film" and figure out that it is a movie, and I can say that word and learn by saying it and memorizing it.  The Japanese version though is not for me.  I click on something and a bunch of Japanese letters pop up on the screen.  How do I read this language without any training?  I literally need to go elsewhere, learn the entire language, and then start to play Influent to learn a few extra words.  Also, they have a voice actor speak the words as I click on things.  While that may seem helpful, it isn't.  It just sounds like randomness.  However, instead of showing me that 'movie' is '映画', it should also say the english phonetically compatible version of 'Eiga', which would be infinitely more useful but still doesn't help in showing me why 'Eiga' is '映画', but it would be a good start.  So basically this software is only an accessory to someone who knows mostly everything and wants to sharpen their skills a little bit, but don't expect to learn a lot by using it.

												Having lived in China for 8 years, as of writing this, and having never actually formally studied Chinese, this "game" helps in two ways.First, it helps fill in some really rudimentary gaps in my vocabulary.Second, it helps to reinforce some of the vocabulary I've heard but not cemented in my mind.When it comes to learning a language, however, it is the person's attitude that makes the real difference. As a game, it's not altogether fun, but it's certainly better than the alternative of trying to learn from a dictionary of random words.

												Up front disclaimer: My wife and I already speak Japanese.Further up front disclaimer: This is only worth a buy if it's on sale.The deal is, this is not how to learn a language.  We bought it to practice Japanese, but the only thing it even offers is a very limited vocabulary learning game that centers entirely around objects in a home.You will not learn to speak a single sentence in Japanese.  Not even to say 'yes' or 'no'.  You will not, at all, learn Japanese.  In fact, many of the words you do learn will mean something else entirely when not in the proper context, so even the vocabulary you pick up is of limited use.I still do like it.  As a vocab trainer, it's pretty cool.  It needs a lot more depth and it needs to be honest about what it is, but on sale it's worth a buy.13 out of 19 muffins.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												It's a good vocabulary learning tool, but it won't teach you a new language. Vocabulary is clay, but possessing clay does not make you a sculptor. If you want to learn a language, this is a great first step. I bought the French pack, and I've "mastered" in game terms 50% of the content in two sessions of playing. But the game only aims to teach you 420 words, which is a very basic vocabulary. The average adult has a vocabulary of 12,000-17,000 words. Furthermore, the game teaches you no grammar. You might know what Yogurt or door mat is after beating a language set, but you won't be able to build a coherent sentence. That's okay. Influent offers a very limited scope, but what it does offer it does rather well. If you are interested in taking the first few steps to learning a language, buy this game. It's worth the $10.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												An interesting and unique approach to learning another language.While a bit cluttered and confusing the moment you jump in, Influent has alot to offer in terms of Edutainment and helps pave the way for other educational titles. What stood out the most to me was the ability within the game to actually choose from a bank of words lying around the typical home, rather than have the game set those words for you. By enabling the user to decides their own words (and which adjectives and verbs to tack on) Influent allows them to study at whatever pace they'd like, and focus on whichever areas they desire. Whether it be trying to figure out the masculine/feminine states of certain pieces of furniture, or memorizing the different parts of a bed, Influent has got you covered.For 10 bucks, it's a definate buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Bought the French pack. Seems pretty cool so far, though I've only spent about a half hour in this. You interact with things in your environment and learn their names in your chosen language, and when you've picked up enough words, you can review them in minigames.I'm not sure I'd recommend this to a total beginner to French. This might be something that comes up later in the game, but I was confused to see that the game omits the proper gender articles for a given word. For instance, the word for "book" is "livre", which the game tells you is "masculine". That's correct, but then the game doesn't tell you what that means.The minigames could use a little bit of work. Time Attack was my favorite one, where you're given a word and you have to run around and find the object the word corresponds to. So if you're given "mur", you have to go and double click on a "wall". It's easy enough, but things get stressful when you have to click very precisely on a really small or skinny object and you're trying to do it as fast as possible to get a good score. I wish the hitboxes had been bigger on these objects, because even if I turn up mouse sensitivity, a stylo is SO MUCH SMALLER than the bureau, and it can be a pain getting my cursors to line up with a tiny object. The sluggish walk controls don't help much either.The other minigame I tried out let you take control of a model plane and zoom around the room shooting objects that match up to a given word. Thing is, you have to shoot several times at an object (presumably to tell the game you REALLY, REALLY, REALLY do know the meaning of that word, even though the repetition isn't a feature of the other minigame) and your plane is constantly moving towards whatever point in space you're focusing on. This means that you have to sometimes turn around to get more breathing room to fire on the object until the game finally tells you you're correct, and THIS is an issue because the plane controls rather sluggishly, and also explodes upon touching just about anything.Still, it was a good refresher for some vocabulary I'd forgotten. I could see this being useful as a side tool for a more in-depth language course.

												From the hour that I've played, i'm able to recommend this game as a suppliment to your learning.This game primarily teaches nouns, with some verbs and adjectives on the side. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Fun little immersive 'quiz' that can help you memorise vocabulary.I see lots of people criticising saying it won't actually teach you the language - well, no, I don't think it was designed for that. Check out the price tag on Rosetta Stone if you want to see what that would cost you. What it is made to do, it does well. By avoiding any grammar at all, and focusing entirely on vocabulary, it is probably in the end better at its goals.Sure, being a beginner and learning the Korean for houseplant might not seem useful, but when you've actually picked some up and want to start 'decorating' your sentences with nouns, that is where this shines. I think too many people were somehow expecting to learn a full language from a cheap-as-chips game.What this does is give me a great alternative to sitting down with mind-numbing flashcards and let me learn in a much more engaging way, and that is all I wanted from this.If I had a couple of criticisms it would be the amount of content and a technical issue. For the content, perhaps the environment could be expanded somewhat (can I at least look down the corridor and find the word for 'elevator'? And the technical issue I've had is that, somewhat bizarrely, the game saves your progress in the Windows registry. This means if you move computer or reinstall windows or something, there are no save game files to copy to the new computer, even if you've made a backup.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												The first thing you need to know about this is that, despite being called "the language learning game", this cannot be used to learn a language to any degree. Don't expect something like Duolingo or Rosetta Stone, which if you don't know are interactive applications which, if used regularly, will essentially provide a sufficiently structured learning plan to allow you to become functionally proficient (IE, able to carry on a simple conversation) in another language.All this game allows you to do is learn basic vocabulary. That's it. You walk around inside a little apartment and click on objects, and the game tells you the name of the object in the language you've chosen, frequently alongside relevant adjectives and verbs (EG, clicking on a candle will tell you the word for "candle" as well as the word for the verb "light"). Then you can create vocabulary lists that will allow you to test your knowledge of these words. It's very good for that, for learning some basic vocabulary in a new language. But it will not do anything else. It won't teach you any sort of grammar; you won't so much as learn how to put together a sentence properly in the subject language. But if you're just learning the basics of a new language, or would like to, then this is good for that. It will help you quickly master a basic vocabulary list which will help you start listening to dialogue or reading or taking a class or doing any of the other things that will help you actually learn a new language.

Posted: January 12, 2016
												This game is exactly as described. It primarily teaches you the names of common household nouns. It's a great way to dip your toes into a new language, establish a basic vocabulary, and get familiar with pronunciation. It does not claim to be an all-in-one learning tool. If you want instant gratification, buy a tourist phrasebook, but if you're willing to put in the time, this game will be a valuable first step in the learning process. I would recommend this game (and have) to people who are thinking about learning a new language. When I started using other tools that taught me to form sentences, I found it handy to have the vocabulary this program taught me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												As a vocab primer, it's fun. My Spanish is OK but I never knew the word for stapler... until now!As a tool for actually learning the language, it's useless. You can wander around someone's house and tell them how to say "light switch", but then when they ask you about literally anything outside the home, you won't even know how to say "what?"While this is a nice idea for immersive learning, and it's fairly well put together, it's really not the "Language Learning Game" that it advertises as, because language learning is about so much more than vocabulary. Put it this way: in the Spanish version, it's optional whether or not to include noun genders. You can't learn Spanish without knowing the gender system. So it doesn't teach you the language. It teaches you some words. That's it.Get DuoLingo if you are a beginner. It's free and a million times better.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												I wanted a language I already knew (Russian) but wanted to brush up on it. I wanted to learn to play the game, but not fight with the language to learn what to do with the game. So I have played this game with Russian many times, and have slowly gotten better with the words I either forgot or didn't know. I really recommend this game, BUT it's a bit tricky. Is it tellling you the color of the item, the size, what it is, what it's for. Because of knowing the language, it has confused me several times. The word does not tell you the context of the word, even with the translation option. In other languages, there can be other meanings to a word that are not what you expected from that item. But one thing is for sure, some of it is funny. I see a word translated, and it's correct and proper, BUT to hear a Russian say the same word for the same item is sometimes weird and funny.  Remember, immersion is the key to learning a language, not translating. I RECOMMEND THIS.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												I've been using Influent to learn Mandarin, and it has been one of the most helpful vocabulary tools I have found. It provides a very clear UI for gamification (although the controls are wonky) and reads words out loud, which is super important trying to learn a tonal language, coming from English. It is a little disappointing with the limited environment, although that environment does contain a massive amount of objects, so it's less of a problem then it could be, and I respect the developer increasing the breadth of languages rather than the depth of each.  I would reccomend looking at this game after looking at other free or cheap language learning tools. It may be you will find one that works very well for you and you won't need to spend money on this game. However, very few free Mandarin sites provided me with the pronunciations I wanted, and the gamification here makes me feel very intensely about wanting to get a random list of 10 words correct.

												This is fun and cute. I got the Japanese one. I would not suggest it if you haven't taken at least an introductory course. I like this because it makes it easier for me to remember a lot of common words. There are a few too many loan words for my taste but not enough for me to not suggest it. It's not really language learning software. It's basically glorified flash cards. It also splits up the pronunciation so you can see which kanji is read in what way in compound spellings. Basically if you want a cute way to remember a lot of every day objects this is great. If you want to get better at recognizing the kanji for every day objects it's great. If you don't already know how to read kana or are not currently learning them separately don't buy this game for Japanese.

I don't recommend this game to everyone. You should be motivated to learn the given language.This game is good at what the developers focussed on. You get dropped into a room and can see what the object is called in the chosen language. However there is no real structure in your approach. You roam the room and add arbitrary words to your list. There is an airplane minigame which to my opinion is totally out of context. And although it is mentioned, the game doesn't focus on sentences. Just vocabulary. However I would have prefered some better testing modes instead of the airplane mode (which is essentially "time attack" from an airplane).Pros:- Clear UI- Easy controls- intuitive word listing- good time attack- rich amount of objects- time attack and random words are good testing methodsCons:- Missing variety in testing methodes- out-of-context airplane game mode- no sentence support- no structured approach of learning

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												Having studied Japanese during my Uni years and now living in Korea, this take on "fun" learning is enjoyable for refreshing and reinforcing previous knowledge. Yes it is limited to only 420 nouns, adj, and verbs, and limited to only 4 rooms in the house, I think it has a lot of potential if the developer expands upon it.Although Japanese and Korean have a lot of borrowed words from English in the game (as previous reviews have complained about), they are used in the language as well, so knowing what is a borrowed word is useful.I wasn't a fan of the flying plane mode as it was a pain to try to focus on smaller objects throughout the house like pens/pencils etc. but a cool concept.The music was relaxing and enjoyable while searching for objects.I look forward to the future prospects of this product, because... genuinely, whatever motivates you to learn a language will get you one step closer to using it and fluency.**On a side note, Achievements took roughly 7 hours for me to complete with a little knowledge in the language I was playing in.**

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												TL:DR summary:This game is not fun and won't help you learn a language.I'm interested in language learning and so I was really excited to try this "game" and see what it brings to the table. I knew about that game for a long time, but with the recent humble bundle, I spent a buck to find out. This is what I think:- I can hardly call this a game. While I really like the "intro-story", the game doesn't build up on the story at all. The whole "game" consists of you running around in your flat and clicking things. Your character isn't talking at all and the only objectives are getting the achievements and/or completing an ingame todo list, which groups certain words thematically. While the latter kept me motivated for a while, but also got me frustrated, since the list contains the "to be learned"-words in target language. So you have no real clue what to look for- You only learn vocabulary. While I'm not a big fan of grammar rules in the form of equations or conjugation tables, this game doesn't contain a single sentence! Only words! Mainly nouns, but later on adjectives and verbs as well. But no sentences!- You don't really learn any vocabulary. I have to major issues. First, the game tells you that you "mastered" a word after several successful training units. However the game doesn't contain any concept about long-term memory. After you learn words in a language, you have to repeat them in growing intervals. Repeat after 1 minute, 15 minutes, an hour, 5 hours, a day, 5 days, a month and so on... this game thinks you "mastered" a word in 3 min. That is not how memory works :( Second: The way the game teaches you is: it shows or tells you a word and you have to find the corresponding object in your flat and click it. However this only builds your passive vocabulary. If you were given a word in your mother tongue and you should translate it to the language you are learning, this game won't really help youSo all in all the "TL:DR summary" is very black and white (in this case black). This software gives you some motivation to learn/repeat words and you might indeed learn a thing or two. If you are just planning to fool around with some vocabulary of a language and spend 2 or 3 hours, this game is fine. For anything else it is really ill fitted. You definetely won't learn a language and I can hardly believe that anyone will build a real vocabulary with this. Rather pick up memrise.com courses or get anki for vocab training,

												I'm using this for Chinese.  I already know some, and this is helping me fill all kinds of absurd holes in my knowledge (I didn't even know that I didn't know how to say "mayo" or "clingwrap" or "blender" etc.)It's not comprehensive, and it won't teach you sentence structure.  For the folks using it to learn Japanese, of course it's going to teach you lots of cognates; that's kind of how Japanese works.  For helping cement and strengthen someone who is already at the strong beginner level in a language, though, it's a very useful and engaging toy....and at this price, it's cheaper and more fun than any language learning toy I've seen.  I recommend it unless you're broke.  If you're broke, maybe take a break from the Steam, huh?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												For learning vocabulary this game is very good but you need to be aware of its limitations:- You are searching for words in a flat. Everything that can reasonably be in a flat is in it. Most of those are really everyday-vocabulary that is useful to know but you also get things like 'coat rack' which might not be something you need in your early everyday-conversations. On the other hand e.g. stuff like 'car' or most animal are missing. Still I'd say that overall the large majority is really useful vocabulary- if you're practising nouns it's obvious how it works: it asks for table and you click on the table but adjectives and verbs it's different: you get them via nouns that have a connection with them. A plant grows, you wash laundry etc. That can get difficult when there is more than one association you can make. A poster might be beautiful but in this game it's only associated with a painting...- you can either practise a list of 10 words that you made or a random list of 10 words. There is no possibility to limit this random list to just those you don't know well, yet. I know that Russian 'banan' means 'banana' by now. I don't need to go over at again and again. A possibility to stop asking for vocabulary you have already mastered would have been nice.For me those are only minor issues and I still think it's a great vocabulary-game.

												It's a nice little vocab builder. All 420 words in the game are moderately useful for day-to-day life. If you were expecting a robust language software, or even something that would let you string a sentence together, this isn't it. But it gamifies learning some useful vocab and it good for getting a feel of the language's phonetics. The only thing I think is lacking )(that I would expect for software this price) is a simple game/tool for other alphabets and the sign/sound correspondences of them. If you're looking at getting a language pack with non-Latin alphabet (e.g. Japanese, Russian), I would suggest learning the alphabet seperately before playing. There are much better free websites (e.g. Memrise) that teach orthography and letter sounds much better than this software.If you want to be fluent, move to another country. If you want to learn a lot about a language, get an expensive software like Rosetta stone. If you want to impress your friends with a few vocab items and learn something while playing seek and find, get Influent.

												This is fun and cute. I got the Japanese one. I would not suggest it if you haven't taken at least an introductory course. I like this because it makes it easier for me to remember a lot of common words. There are a few too many loan words for my taste but not enough for me to not suggest it. It's not really language learning software. It's basically glorified flash cards. It also splits up the pronunciation so you can see which kanji is read in what way in compound spellings. Basically if you want a cute way to remember a lot of every day objects this is great. If you want to get better at recognizing the kanji for every day objects it's great. If you don't already know how to read kana or are not currently learning them separately don't buy this game for Japanese.

I don't recommend this game to everyone. You should be motivated to learn the given language.This game is good at what the developers focussed on. You get dropped into a room and can see what the object is called in the chosen language. However there is no real structure in your approach. You roam the room and add arbitrary words to your list. There is an airplane minigame which to my opinion is totally out of context. And although it is mentioned, the game doesn't focus on sentences. Just vocabulary. However I would have prefered some better testing modes instead of the airplane mode (which is essentially "time attack" from an airplane).Pros:- Clear UI- Easy controls- intuitive word listing- good time attack- rich amount of objects- time attack and random words are good testing methodsCons:- Missing variety in testing methodes- out-of-context airplane game mode- no sentence support- no structured approach of learning

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												This is not a learning tool. It's a fetch quest generator in disguise.You point to objects in the room and add them to the list, then you need to find these objects from the list of 10. Imagine running through the room from fridge to sofa to the baseball under the bed. In case this might be boring, there's another mode this game provides: you're a miniature plane, you fly (pretty fast) and shoot same objects from the same list.Thus, by tens you 'learn' the words. But you're no caveman - you find an object three times in a row, you learn it. That's it, it will never fade from your memory. Well done. 420 words is all you need anyway.There are better (and free) ways to expand your vocabulary and learn the language in general. Look up Duolingo or Memrise, to name a couple.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												So I have the Chinese and Spanish.For The game in general, The way it work is that you are in an apartment you get to explore. You  the ability to switch between third person and first person, and the bases of the game is that you click on objects, the game pronounces the word, the transation and shows the word. you then have the choice to add the word to your vocab list. This applies for nouns and verbs with the verbs being attached to an object that is related to the verb ( for example, the verb "To watch" is attached to the Television). for every ten words you select to add, a new list consisting of just those words in made, and then you are able to test yourself on the list. the test works  be you get the option to isolate how much of the word you get in order find the object (For example, you can choice to have just the word appear with no voice or clues to the direction of the object, or you can just pick to hear the voice and no text to aid you).You progress in the game by testing youself on these words you obtain, and then successfully picking any word three times in a row. once you do that, you receive a gold star ( which is used to buy verbs and adjectives off of objects) and the word is considered mastered. you beat the game by mastering all the words of all the objects in the apartment.For any langauge, this game is a perfect way to improve your ear for the langauge and to better introduce yourself with more vocabulary.now to the langaugesThe Chinese is nice, it has a selection to do pinyin and later characters. The tones for each word is clear, the speaker is very good at what it's doing. The problem is that you often will recieve a word with synonyms, which happens in each language, but with Mandarin chinese being so regional, the game doesn't explain which words are used where (Such as tailand or main land china.)Spanish is great, the pronounciations are clear, with the speaker leaning towards a latin american accent. the langauge is standard, with the words you receive being the most understood word, with synonyms being out shined by this standard words. again, a problem is that the game doesnt explain which words are used where, but I guess you can google it or something. not much more to say,Not a good game to learn a langauge's grammer,a great game for people with an understanding of a language's grammer that want to expand thier vocab.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												You can tell by my hours played that I didn't play this game that long. This isn't just because I didn't want to play anymore, but because I was skeptical that I'd further my education by doing so.To begin with, the game environment is uncomfortable. You're confined to an extremely small apartment, with 400 objects you can learn to say in one of twelve languages. The amount of stuff cramped into such a tiny area makes it feel even more claustrophobic than it would as just an unfurnished area, which makes me feel like shutting off the game right from the beginning. This is especially true if you're playing in third person, which means your character model is added to it all. I don't know much about what can and can't be patched, but I'd like to suggest to the dev if it's possible to edit the map so that the 3 rooms are at least a few feet wider, and have some of the furniture spaced out a bit as well.The actual objects themselves aren't very fun to look at either (except for the Cowboy Bebop reference in one of the posters!). Everything is completely static, and the only interaction available with them is to find out the word for them in your chosen language. This might seem like all that you'd need, but with the actual quizzing being so basic, it makes things really boring when you literally can do nothing else. It'd be cool if some objects had animations (especially the doors, which I desperately wanted to open for some more space), or even physics that let you drag them around.One small complaint to add before moving on to my biggest one: while the one track available is actually very enjoyable, there needs to be more songs added. I think I'd go crazy if I had to listen to that same song over and over for more than an hour.Now my biggest problem of all isn't really relevant for people who aren't learning Japanese: There's no focus on the Kanji. In the Japanese language, Kanji is /VERY/ crucial to being able to read or write anything. Yes, it is included in the game, but there's nothing to help you remember the details of it, let alone the stroke order for writing it. Without that, it's fairly pointless to play the game at all for anything besides listening practice, but even for that you'd be better off watching anime and/or Japanese films, and listening to Japanese music and podcasts.For vocabularly, I personally would suggest downloading a free language learning program called "Anki", and then dowloading (also free) both the Heisig Kanji card pack, and the Japanese Core 2k pack. Some untranslated mangas are decent practice as well.The developer for this game obviously had great intentions, and on paper his concept is great. But in execution, not so much.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												It should be noted firstly that Influent is a vocabulary expansion tool, not a language learning tool. It boasts the ability to teach up to 420 words in whichever language you choose. Yes, you could find all of the words online, but Influent has the element of interactivity. It is unbelievably convenient and useful to be able to actually see the things related to what you are learning. There is a very noticeable and evident difference between learning a word and (perhaps) seeing a picture, and learning a word in an interactive space. Seeing a word in an interactive space makes, truly, all the difference.     The downsides to the game include a limited gameplay space, and thus limited word choice. A certain 'word bias', I suppose (there is a cat, but no dog, and a cactus but no flower, for example). It would be greatly appreciated if, later on, there was some world expansion DLC that included a new place to explore --- if the developers are reading this, I'm recommending a small store or shop, that would be nice.    Overall, it is certainly a good game, and it is worth CAD 10.99. I would recommend this game to people who have learned or are learning the grammar to their chosen language and who are looking to expand their vocabulary.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												I got the spanish pack with the Humble Bundle.I've gotten to about 170 words so far. Pretty enjoyable pace. You have the option of hearing a word as well as reading, or you can disanle one and use the other. The real game side of things is the ten question quiz, which has you going around via walking or flying a space ship toy and finding the objects it names (or another word attached to said object). Having never taken a Spanish class the thing I found so surprising is that plenty of words are so similar!The word for newspaper sounds like periodical. The word for spatula is espatula. The word for skateboard is skateboard, the word for CD is CD. The word for poster is poster.  THE WORD FOR SANDWICH IS SANDWICH! It really blew my mind.A window sounds like a vent (ventana). So many words that are easy to pick up because they sound similar. It's great! If I had to make a complaint, it's that not all the audio recordings are very clear (MOST OF THEM ARE) so there's a few words where is feels like they started recording a quarter second too late: a V will sound like a B,  an R will sound like a D. Some suffer noise pollution: ruedecilla (stove knob) for example has an odd beep in front of it. But on the whole, the game is worth getting. It's a pretty entertaining approach and I think I'll spend some more time on it.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												This game is centered around learning vocabulary and that is it.  Gameplay centers around exploration of your limited environment in order to pick out objects that you come across.  It then gives fun little quizzes that ask you to find the objects in your environment.  For its intended task, it is great and works well.  Influent's only downfall is that everything you learn will be individualized nouns.  From my experience, it does not introduce verbs, sentence structure, etc.  If someone goes into the game thinking it will be a full language course, then they will be dissappointed.  If they go in looking at Influent from the perspective of a fun tool to help master some common objects, they will be very happy with their purchase.I can't wait to see how the game evolves.  I can see the game expanding into explorations outside of the small aparment and into the world with further exploration of items.  Then expanding further to have the user build sentences to interact with the environment or even order food at restaurants.  If the developer takes it that far, they will be in a full league/class of their own for interactive linguistic education.  Great start to a product with loads of oppurtunity to expand.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												I've been using Influent to learn Mandarin, and it has been one of the most helpful vocabulary tools I have found. It provides a very clear UI for gamification (although the controls are wonky) and reads words out loud, which is super important trying to learn a tonal language, coming from English. It is a little disappointing with the limited environment, although that environment does contain a massive amount of objects, so it's less of a problem then it could be, and I respect the developer increasing the breadth of languages rather than the depth of each.  I would reccomend looking at this game after looking at other free or cheap language learning tools. It may be you will find one that works very well for you and you won't need to spend money on this game. However, very few free Mandarin sites provided me with the pronunciations I wanted, and the gamification here makes me feel very intensely about wanting to get a random list of 10 words correct.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												To clear up any confusion, Influent is not "a Language Learning Game focusing primarily on vocabulary". It is purely a vocabulary builder and nothing else.Having said that, it is the best example of turning the boring task of vocabulary memorisation into a game that I have seen. I have "mastered" over 400 words and it was actually *fun* to do so, which is something I can't say for books or flashcards. Assigning the words to virtual objects has really helped me remember them. The testing method involves hunting down items that belong to lists of 10 words at a time. It's quite limited in this regard but it's not bad.I'm using the Norwegian DLC so can't comment on the accuracy of other languages, but I have found one incorrect word so be sure to check against a dictionary when learning / playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Excellent for learning hotel languages. While it won't help you with grammar and formulating sentences (head to duolingo for that, which is free), helping you memorize 420 vocabulary words with a video game is pretty great. It'll get you started and keep you interested as opposed to trying to learn from scratch with websites. With those, the second you get burnt out, you're more likely to quit and put it off for some unknown future date. But if you're playing a game that consists of learning what's in your house, it's hard not to continue reminding yourself of the words. Hell, I've caught myself going to il frigorifero at night for uno spuntino. If it's on sale, get it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Influent is an interesting little game that could use a little work. I'm impressed that there's a Latin version, which is what I bought. I've studied Latin for years yet never learned any neo-latin words (as many modern household items don't have names in classical latin). Gameplay is simple: click on an object and see/hear the translation. However I wish the game also displayed the name of the item alongside the translated name, as many of the Latin names for items end up being noun - adjective combinations. Doube clicking on an object provides a little extra info, but for Latin it's really only the gender of the noun. Including the principal parts or declension could really improve the usefulness of this tool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												The game initially was a fun to start learning a language. It's very similar to learning from flash cards but it includes verbal cues. My main problem with the game is with its terrible word list system. You select objects and add them to your vocabulary list. The list is broken up into groups of 10 words. To learn the words you must pick a list of 10 and test yourself on it. Organizing words in these lists is a nightmare since you can only swap 2 words at a time. With 400+ words in the game this becomes nearly impossible to organize. Also, you can't remove words you've added to your list or even move them to a "learn later" section.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												This is not a learning tool. It's a fetch quest generator in disguise.You point to objects in the room and add them to the list, then you need to find these objects from the list of 10. Imagine running through the room from fridge to sofa to the baseball under the bed. In case this might be boring, there's another mode this game provides: you're a miniature plane, you fly (pretty fast) and shoot same objects from the same list.Thus, by tens you 'learn' the words. But you're no caveman - you find an object three times in a row, you learn it. That's it, it will never fade from your memory. Well done. 420 words is all you need anyway.There are better (and free) ways to expand your vocabulary and learn the language in general. Look up Duolingo or Memrise, to name a couple.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Holy crap!  This is the second greatest language learning program ever created!!!As a disclosure--I do not know the developers.  I have never met them.  I was not part of the kickstarter.  Literally the first I ever heard of this program was when it was in a Humble Bundle this week.  I had all the other software, but this program/game interested me.  When I found it on sale in Steam, I pounced.I purchased the base "game" for Spanish, and the add-ons for Mandarin, Japanese, Russian, Korean and Latin.  I would have purchased at least 2 more (Dutch and Gaelic) had they been available.  At $2.50/per language, why would you not?I have now played a touch with each language, and I have to say that it is amazing.  It is a brilliant idea, and it is wonderfully executed.  Click an object, hear it's name.  Double click and see how it's written.  This software will NOT teach you a language.  You wil HAVE to augment it with some other form of learning.  What it will do (at least according to a few minutes of testing) is give you a larger vocabulary of nouns.  While not all that you need, nouns are a big part of what you will use.  BUY IT!!!!

												This game is great, learning this way is better than going to classes. I would greatly recomment this game to learn some basic vocabulary, verbs and adjectives. For me I'm doing Korean right now. However this is not going to get you speak the language fluently, it does however help you learn new words. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												For learning vocabulary this game is very good but you need to be aware of its limitations:- You are searching for words in a flat. Everything that can reasonably be in a flat is in it. Most of those are really everyday-vocabulary that is useful to know but you also get things like 'coat rack' which might not be something you need in your early everyday-conversations. On the other hand e.g. stuff like 'car' or most animal are missing. Still I'd say that overall the large majority is really useful vocabulary- if you're practising nouns it's obvious how it works: it asks for table and you click on the table but adjectives and verbs it's different: you get them via nouns that have a connection with them. A plant grows, you wash laundry etc. That can get difficult when there is more than one association you can make. A poster might be beautiful but in this game it's only associated with a painting...- you can either practise a list of 10 words that you made or a random list of 10 words. There is no possibility to limit this random list to just those you don't know well, yet. I know that Russian 'banan' means 'banana' by now. I don't need to go over at again and again. A possibility to stop asking for vocabulary you have already mastered would have been nice.For me those are only minor issues and I still think it's a great vocabulary-game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												It's a nice little vocab builder. All 420 words in the game are moderately useful for day-to-day life. If you were expecting a robust language software, or even something that would let you string a sentence together, this isn't it. But it gamifies learning some useful vocab and it good for getting a feel of the language's phonetics. The only thing I think is lacking )(that I would expect for software this price) is a simple game/tool for other alphabets and the sign/sound correspondences of them. If you're looking at getting a language pack with non-Latin alphabet (e.g. Japanese, Russian), I would suggest learning the alphabet seperately before playing. There are much better free websites (e.g. Memrise) that teach orthography and letter sounds much better than this software.If you want to be fluent, move to another country. If you want to learn a lot about a language, get an expensive software like Rosetta stone. If you want to impress your friends with a few vocab items and learn something while playing seek and find, get Influent.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Wonderful, just wonderful.From music 'so chill', to effective learning techniques that address kinesthetic; auditory; and visual learning styles, to just being pleasant as a whole to experience and easy to operate with a shallow learning curve that anyone with patience can learn (even if they don't 'game'), this game excels. And, contrary to popular belief found in the reviews I've read, this game also teaches you verbs and adjectives, along with actual objects.This game will indeed not teach you an entire language (like I thought it would from first impression before reading further), but it teaches you more-than-basic (as in diverse) basic vocabulary, actions and description-words. 400 new words (not individual words I think, so more like 400 things) per language? Bring it on.I picked up the Japanese version and am having fun coming back to it here and there to expand my knowledge and learn.TL;DRThis is a good, fun and painless supplemental and standalone tool that can be used to expand your knowledge in one or more of the several languages offered, though it isn't a comprehensive course. Recommended.- Yoko

												I received this game through a recent Humble Bundle and it's been a pleasant surprise.  I'm not certain if I made a mistake when it was purchased...but when it first started up, English was the only selection.  I did not have an option of choosing which languange I'd like to learn.  I went ahead and purchsed two language packs and have been progressing quickly.The game will get you to understand many items you'd find around the house, but I'd like to see the development of an outside/office/public area.  Also, other mini-games involving potential sentance structure would be great. One last nit-pick:  The random word list is fantastic...but as I'm adding more words to the list, I'd really like to focus more on the newer words rather than a truely random selection.  I've been getting the first 20 words that I've mastered repeatedly, even as I move onward to 150-200 words listed.It's worth picking up, rather fun, but has significant room for growth!

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I'm using this for Chinese.  I already know some, and this is helping me fill all kinds of absurd holes in my knowledge (I didn't even know that I didn't know how to say "mayo" or "clingwrap" or "blender" etc.)It's not comprehensive, and it won't teach you sentence structure.  For the folks using it to learn Japanese, of course it's going to teach you lots of cognates; that's kind of how Japanese works.  For helping cement and strengthen someone who is already at the strong beginner level in a language, though, it's a very useful and engaging toy....and at this price, it's cheaper and more fun than any language learning toy I've seen.  I recommend it unless you're broke.  If you're broke, maybe take a break from the Steam, huh?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Awesome idea but a claustrophobic experienceThe idea is quite good, there a lot of objects to learn, quite common and useful. It starts great, discovering new words and practicing. It has good graphics, it's really cheap, and the sound quality it's very good.The problem is after the first hour or two, it's not a game to finish in one setting, but the more you play the more boring it gets. There is some of the points I'd like to mention. -The music is great, but there are only 2 tracks, and this is a spaced repetition method, so, after a while of repetitions, it becames dull. -There is a story in the trailer, and you expect to visit all those cool locations to help Andrew Cross with his invention, but in the end nothing happen, maybe he is a NEET and that's why he is intented to solve his case sorely in his house.-There are not recorded articles (like "la" or "el" in spanish) with the words, which it's very important to remember when learning gender nouns in languages like Spanish, French or German. -The plane mode is useless, maybe in an open space would rock. -There are some western words that maybe you wont need in your target language, and there are a lot of words that are common in one country but there's no sign here. -Dlc is more like a traduction than a localization. Same content for all languages. If you plan to learn a new language, try it with another method, it's good for some vocabulary.  ---A note for developers: Why not put more areas instead of more languages. A lot of people think the product is "incomplete", because the trailer makes you think there's more to discover. It feels like you are milking the same assets. If you decide to improved the content I'd gladly change my review. ---Also I made a workshop for the program Controller Companion for this game, so you can use your gamepad, Check it out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												This is my first review so I will just say the most important things. To give you a better inside of my experience, my native language is german and I bought the japanese pack.To all of the people who blamed this game for not teaching them the complete language with all its grammer rules. That is not what this game is supposed to do. This game will not teach you a language from scratch and it doesn`t have to. If you only want to learn a language by using only one source than this would definately not be your kind of game. But let´s be serious guys. I think we all should know that learning a language requires far more different materials and takes a♥♥♥♥♥♥load of time. This game is just for Vocabs and therefore should be used as additional tool beside your other study methods. Of course you will have to learn grammer and sentence structure seperately by using books or taking courses but that is to be expected. Long story short. This game mainly serves as a Vocabulary trainer. You have to think for yourself if it´s worth buying "just" for that. But I for myself consider it way more fun to actively learn the vocabs than to read them of some flash cards. (which for japanese easily cost double the price/ Kanji readings ect.)Lastly a little review specially for the japanese pack:Pro- The voice is good- it has many words for everday use- switchable between Hiragana, Kanji and romaji- you feel succesfull- more translations for the same wordCon- Just household items - just a flat to move in- many english words in a japanese manner (can be avoided by taking another word with same meaning)5/7  would recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												In Influent you move around an appartment clicking on items to recieve a translation of noun and sometimes a adjectives or verbs associated with the item. After adding ten item words to your list you can then play a memory game to recall the item words are associated with. For more of a challenge you can turn off the sound or text for the words being requested. There is also a shooting mode where you fly a model plane to shoot the item associated with the requested word.That is essentially all there is to this game. It is a memory game where instead of choosing multiple choice answers for a word you can click on anything in the appartment to match the word. The Adjectives and Verbs are also made easier to associate because the associated Noun is written in brackets after the word (ie. "Interesting [book]" ). This game is a useful tool to help you build associations between household items and associated nouns, adjectives and verbs. - just a pitty some more interesting locations and items aren't included. It would had been nice for a museum so I could see words used for parts of machines and tools, or somewhere more public (like a train or bus stop) so words associated with people and purchasing or travelling could be included.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												First of all I would only reccommend it, if you get it on sale. Since 10$ are just too much for a tiny 3D environment and some voice effects. Also there seem to be no updates (its almost 2 years since release and no additional rooms/words have been added).Of course the game cannot teach you any grammar, and its just a small tool that can help you if you use it properly. If you already have a basic understanding of the language and writing system you want to learn, then it can really be a fun additional exercise to extend your vocabulary. The vocabulary in this game is not top priority stuff for beginners, but if your goal is to become fluent in the language you will have to learn all these everyday objects sooner or later.You can build a vocabulary list by clicking on various items, then do a "race" challenge where the names pop up and you have to find the corresponding items. The vocabulary tool keeps track of how well you remember the words, although this is very rudimentary (a red/yellow/green symbol). By doing well in these races you unlock points with which you can unlock adjectives or verbs related to the nouns in the game. This extends the vocabulary of the whole apartment to several hundred words, enough to keep you busy.Overall, I think the game is useful if you are self-studying a language and sometimes need a little motivational boost. It helps pick up some new words with correct pronunciation, but afterwards to keep them in long term memory, I would move them into a spaced repetition tool like Anki.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
 Fantastic educational tool for those with realistic expectationsThis game is a fun and useful addition to a growing pool of inexpensive or free language learning software. While not a comprehensive course, Influent presents a truly impressive model for the gamification of acquiring basic vocabulary. Players find themselves navigating a 3D home with hundreds of objects to interact with. As you explore, vocab sheets are created which you can later test your knowledge of by associating objects with presented words (unfortunately the opposite has not be implemented). With over 400 nouns, adjectives, and verbs, players can use the game as a jumping off point for learning a new language. When you combine with something like Duolingo, it becomes apparent how wonderful the digital age is for those of us who love to learn!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												This is a great supplement to drilling vocabulary for a language. However, it is greatly limited by the objects within the game.What is wonderful about it is that it tries to mimic your household items. So even when you're not playing, you can look around your room and try to recall or speak out the words you've been practicing.This is slightly more advantageous then drilling a set list of vocab words in a 101 book, or from a class. As those list are fixed to a lesson plan, and it's a bit harder to grasp as you are relying more on flash cards rather than visual associations to the object or action.I recommend this to anyone who wants to increase their elementary vocabulary of a language while learning a new language. This however, does not help you construct any grammatically correct sentences for said language, nor would it help you with verb tenses nor particles.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												To clear up any confusion, Influent is not "a Language Learning Game focusing primarily on vocabulary". It is purely a vocabulary builder and nothing else.Having said that, it is the best example of turning the boring task of vocabulary memorisation into a game that I have seen. I have "mastered" over 400 words and it was actually *fun* to do so, which is something I can't say for books or flashcards. Assigning the words to virtual objects has really helped me remember them. The testing method involves hunting down items that belong to lists of 10 words at a time. It's quite limited in this regard but it's not bad.I'm using the Norwegian DLC so can't comment on the accuracy of other languages, but I have found one incorrect word so be sure to check against a dictionary when learning / playing.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I wanted a language I already knew (Russian) but wanted to brush up on it. I wanted to learn to play the game, but not fight with the language to learn what to do with the game. So I have played this game with Russian many times, and have slowly gotten better with the words I either forgot or didn't know. I really recommend this game, BUT it's a bit tricky. Is it tellling you the color of the item, the size, what it is, what it's for. Because of knowing the language, it has confused me several times. The word does not tell you the context of the word, even with the translation option. In other languages, there can be other meanings to a word that are not what you expected from that item. But one thing is for sure, some of it is funny. I see a word translated, and it's correct and proper, BUT to hear a Russian say the same word for the same item is sometimes weird and funny.  Remember, immersion is the key to learning a language, not translating. I RECOMMEND THIS.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												First of all I know I havent spend much time in this game yet, but it is really awesome.I have the Japanese dlc, but I think it would be the same no matter what language you go for. EDIT: Got a few more language packs and they do are in essence the same as the Japanese languange packEverything in this game can be clicked and for everything clicked you will hear the word and then be able to see it written, rehear it and see what it looks like at the same time in your vocabulary list. You choose if you want to see the word written out in english aswell. You then master each word (getting it right several times in a row while using time attack) and thus complete your tasks.Its not easy, because you have to remember a lot of words, but thats what makes it so great. You actually have to remember the words (10 words to be mastered for each time attack). You'll then notice how you remember what these things are called in real life aswell.EDIT: Mastering and finding all the word is hard. You might want to check a guide, in order to find all the words.The developers are very into the game and they keep adding new language packs and are working to expand the game, so you'll have more areas to explore and new words to learn. They're a 2 man team and they're doing a great job keeping up and giving us updates on their progress.Buy this game if you want to expand the vocabulary of a language that you're learning. I would even recommend buying at the full price, since it's cheap for such a great game. 10/10

												I picked this up to supplement Duolingo. I like that several languages are supported, so you can live those polyglot dreams.There are frustrating points though, mainly the controls. You are tested by finding objects in your apartment, sometimes it's hard to get over to the thing you want in time. Clicking the fridge when you meant to click the butter *barely* taller than its shelf or trying to click something really small while feeling rushed by the timer. There are no other people to interact with and you are stuck in your house.It also doesn't teach you to use the language so much as builds your vocabulary of household objects. Despite these shortcomings, it's a great way to break up the routine of learning. Don't expect it to be all you need, but a nice diversion in the right direction.

												I played it for a bit and I can say I really like it. Unfortunally it does lack some diversity. Adding some different game modes or even more space to walk, because it´s not a lot, would be wonderful. Just a small thing. Also some minor flaws with articles and their gender, but nothing shocking really.Since it had a 50% discount for my learning language (Italian), it´s worth it to me. Boosting my  day to day vocab in a playful manner is really joyful compaired to boring abstract book reading.I therefore recommend this game for those who need to quickly boost some general vocab. But naturally this game won't make you fluent. If you want to make the most of it, try to think of ways to enhance the learning experiance by speaking about the objects to yourself out loud. Like: That book seems bigger than the toaster over there! or: Darn, I forgot my keys, where were they? Were they next to my wallet on the cabinet?Just great fun, but 10 euro is a bit too much for what you get when thinking about it. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23
												A great game with the understanding that it is strictly vocabulary based. 400 words is enough to get you started learning a language. With that said, if you are learning a non-latin based character system (as in, your language does not using letters "abc" but instead uses Chinese or Russian "letters"), you will need to learn that on your own, as this game does not teach this to you. I purchased the Russian starter pack, and luckily for me, I already learned the Russian "alphabet" before purchasing.I like how relaxed the environment is in the game, and that you can interact with virtually anything within the environment. It's fun to learn, and effective. I'm planning on picking up a French and Danish language pack soon. For $10.00, it's definitly worth the purchase. It really does help you learn solid vocab. I hope the developer continues working on this game, because this could really help a lot of people truly learn a language. I would definitely support this project. Now for some recommendations: I wish the game could have extended its boundaries to an outside world, such as a playground, a school, etc. It would have been nice to get more than roughly 400 words, and to be able to learn grammar. Maybe an interactive story where you practice grammar? The possibilities are endless.

This is great for absolute beginners to a new language, as it teaches you some basic nouns, verbs, and adjectives in a hands-on kind of way. The only downside is that it feels like the first level of what should be a much longer game. I'd be happy to pay for DLC packs in other game environments, like an office, a general store, a grocery store, classroom, etc. It would be great to get some basic phrases or questions worked in as well. I hope the developer adds these features in the future.

Posted: March 2
												Great tool for vocabulary building. Having a second installment that deals with basic grammar would be a great addition to the Influent family. It was enjoyable wandering around the house and trying to find as many things to name as possible. That said, my greatest enjoyment still came from the store comments from players describing their hellish experiences in a house that they can never leave, surrounded forever by objects that they speak the names of over and over again, slowly losing their minds. It's not a "game", so bear that in mind when playing. It's an interactive learning tool, and I will rate it according to that.7/10, nice concept and pretty useful learning supplement.

content:
Posted: April 17
												I bought this game for my toddler who has been in Russian language classes for a few months now. She's been picking it up slowly over time and recently began to ask newer words on her own so figured it was time to try this game out. She immediately loved it. I let her pick which objects she learnt the words for and made it easier for her to learn, since she was directing her own learning and was more meaningful for her. That said, like all the negative reviews I'd LOVE to see a bigger environment: an office, classroom, street view, etc. More common things that would be useful to know if you're were just starting a language. That said this program is not good for learning how to speak a language. I having studied Russian in the past while living there and my daughter being in a class has filled that void, this program simply teaches more words for her arsenal. It MUST be supplemented with an actual language program that teaches sentence structure and grammar but is a good way to learn words in a fun way on your own. All in all this game serves its purpose, it teaches you words that you'd likely need to know in a foreign language especially if you were to travel there and know nothing of the language at least you'd be able to say: toilet, sandwich, soap, etc if you needed to buy something on the economy. Obviously, you'd look crazy if you were just saying random words but it would let you survive for a bit. Still I'd love to see more environments but for the price you get what you pay for which isn't bad. Suggestion: newer environments as DLC, therefore it’s not free to the developer and still keeps the game fresh and the knowledge flowing like a river.
